profile.name: Linus Torvalds
profile.bio: Creator of Linux & Git. Kernel architect. Still passionate about performance & C. Exploring AI's potential and its impact on systems. Occasional rant. @LinuxFoundation | Portland, OR

tweets.content: The pace of front-end framework churn is astounding. It's easy to get caught up in the hype cycles, but true value comes from solving problems, not just using the latest tool. #WebDev
Just spent an hour reviewing an obscure patch for an old tool I use. Small contributions matter, keeping the gears turning. Don't underestimate maintenance. #OpenSource
Still convinced that the best code is the simplest code. If you can't explain your architecture in 5 minutes, it's too complex. #SoftwareDesign #Simplicity
Had a good discussion today about technical debt. It's not just 'bad code,' it's strategic decisions that traded short-term velocity for long-term burden. Managing it is key. #TeamWork #TechDebt
Been reading up on Rust's async story again. The compile-time guarantees are compelling, but the learning curve for advanced patterns... whew. Still worth it? #RustLang

Exploring alternative database technologies beyond relational. Document stores, graph DBs... each with their own trade-offs. No one-size-fits-all, as always. What's your go-to for complex relationships? #Databases

Dependency bloat is a real problem. Every new library pulls in N more, creating an unmanageable tree. Sometimes, just writing a few lines yourself is the more robust long-term solution. #SoftwareEngineering
Finished a tricky refactor today. It felt like untangling a ball of yarn that had been through a shredder. The code is cleaner, the tests pass. Small wins keep you going. #SoftwareDevelopment
Working on a small command-line utility for personal use. It's refreshing to build something simple, focused, and without a huge build system. Back to basics. #CLI #Programming
Thinking about contributing to an older project that's still critical but less actively developed. The challenge of understanding legacy codebases is immense, but the impact could be huge. #FOSS
My tests pass, my deployment succeeded, and my monitoring shows green. I feel an irrational sense of dread. What did I miss? #ImminentFailure
Found a bug that only manifests on Tuesdays when Mercury is in retrograde. Guess I'll just wait for the planet to move. #DebuggingLife
My code is like a toddler: I created it, I love it, but I have no idea why it does half the things it does sometimes. #DevLife

Attended an online meetup discussing the health of a lesser-known but essential open-source library. The community efforts behind these projects are truly inspiring. Support your dependencies! #Community
Unpopular opinion: Microservices aren't a silver bullet. Sometimes, a well-architected monolith is just... better. Simpler to deploy, easier to reason about. Prove me wrong. #Architecture #Monolith
Performance still matters. A lot. We've optimized developer experience at the cost of user experience in too many places. Time to re-evaluate. #PerformanceMatters #WebPerformance

Saw an article about the latest 'AI-powered code generator'. Remember when we thought auto-complete was magic? Now we're getting whole functions. The future is weird, and still needs human review. [link to tech news article]
Just spent 30 minutes trying to figure out why my code wasn't working, only to realize I was on the wrong branch. Happens to the best of us, right? ...right? #GitFail
